                                    <li data-index="1" class="in-view">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title noneIMP">Introduction</h2>
                                        <p>Switzerland is one of those countries that you can never get enough of. Every season is tempting and has something different to offer. We recently spent <a href="/blog/switzerland-itinerary-6-days" class="lnks" target="_blank">6 days in Switzerland</a> in September and now think that this is our new favourite season in Switzerland!</p>
                                        <p>Of course,we loved the winter and <a href="/blog/10-things-to-do-in-switzerland-in-summer" class="lnks" target="_blank">summer in Switzerland</a> summer in Switzerland, too.</p>
                                        <p>Overview of 6 days Switzerland itinerary:</p>
                                        <span>Day 1: Geneva</span>
                                        <ul>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       UN Headquarters</li>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       CERN</li>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Lake Genevan</li>

                                        </ul>
                                        <span>Day 2: Zermatt</span>
                                        <ul>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Matterhorn Glacier Paradise</li>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Sunnegga</li>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Zermatt’s Old Town</li>

                                        </ul>
                                        <span>Day 3: Interlaken</span>
                                        <ul>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Jetboat Ride</li>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Hoheweg</li>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Harder Kulm</li>

                                        </ul>
                                        <span>Day 4: Jungfraujoch </span>
                                        <ul>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Ice Palace</li>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Observation Deck</li>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Alpine Sensation</li>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Lindt Chocolate Heaven</li>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Trummelbach Falls or Grindelwald</li>

                                        </ul>
                                        <span>Day 5: Aletsch Arena</span>
                                        <ul>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Bettmeralp Village</li>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Aletsch Arena</li>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Brig</li>
                                        </ul>
                                        <span>Day 6: Zurich</span>
                                        <ul>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Rhine Falls</li>
                                            <li style='margin-left: 15px;'>-       Shopping</li>

                                        </ul>
                                        <p>Here’s a deep-dive on what we did on our 6 Day in Switzerland itinerary.</p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="2">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Day 1: Lucerne</h2>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/cern-switzerland.jpg" alt="cern switzerland" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>Having arrived at Geneva airport early morning at 6:00 am, we decided to see the city before heading to Zermatt.Depositing the bags and freshening up at the airport, we started our tour with the help of our <a href="/swiss-travel-pass" class="lnks" target="_blank">Swiss Travel Pass</a>,which we had luckily pre-purchased.</p>
                                        <p>One must most certainly look at the Swiss Travel Pass as it offers various discounts and benefits and free access to all public transport in the whole of Switzerland.Also,kids under 16 years travel free when their parents hold the pass.</p>
                                        <p>Our first halt was at the UN Headquarters (30 minutes from Geneva airport). Since we knew exactly what we wanted to cover in the day,we had pre-booked a guided tour on their website. That was clearly a good decision.</p>
                                        <p>The next halt was at the CERN (40 minutes), one of the most respected Scientific research centres in the world, is known for its LHC (Large Hadron Collider) experiment.They offer free guided tours that are really interesting.</p>
                                        <p>Last halt - Lake Geneva (35 minutes). Unfortunately,we did not have time to do a cruise, but ideally that would have been perfect.We spent some time along the promenade and had to make do with a long-distance view of the amazing Jet d’Eau, but the day in Geneva was worth it.</p>
                                        <p>We had to return to the airport, collect our bags and head off to Zermatt</p>
                                        <p>Travel time Geneva airport to Zermatt:3.55 hours with one change at Visp.</p>
                                        <p>We had booked an <a href="/apartments" class="lnks" target="_blank">apartment in Switzerland</a>; so we picked up some food along the way to it and decided to call it a night.</p>
                                        <span>Travel tip:</span>
                                        <p>Zermatt is car-free, so try and book a hotel or apartment that offers a pick up from the station (our apartment offered this as a complimentary service but some charge a nominal fee)</p>
                                        <p>If you can stretch your accommodation budget, please do it here. Nothing can compare to waking up to a view of the Matterhorn.</p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="3">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Day 2: Zermatt – Matterhorn and Sunnegga</h2>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/matterhorn-glacier-paradise-gondola-zermatt.jpg" alt="matterhorn glacier paradise  gondola zermatt" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>We had heard so much about aiming for the best views of the Matterhorn that we decided to go to two of the famous viewing points. The first was the <a href="/mountain-excursion/7-matterhorn-glacier-paradise" class="lnks" target="_blank">Matterhorn Glacier Paradise.</a></p>
                                        <p>Of course, another major reason to choose this was the snow.The Matterhorn Glacier Paradise promises snow all year round. </p>
                                        <p>A walk through the centre of the village had us passing by stores,souvenir shops and cafes with their fresh croissants and intoxicating smell of coffee. </p>
                                        <p>We had booked our excursion tickets in advance at the <a href="/blog/top-discounts-on-swiss-travel-pass" class="lnks" target="_blank">discount with Swiss Travel Pass.</a></p>
                                        <p>We changed 2 cable cars before we reached the peak via some glorious views.In hindsight, it would have been nice to try one of the Swarovski Crystal cable cars have transparent floors that allow you to get a vertical view as you go higher. </p>
                                        <p>On top,we felt enveloped by the snow. After some time of being in the outdoors and clicking photos,we headed to the Glacier Palace.This is literally 15 metres below the glacier's surface and has some ice sculptures, and an ice toboggan run.A quick lunch at the restaurant, and we were ready to leave. </p>
                                        <p>Once back down,we walked into Zermatt’s Old Town (Hinterdorf, which literally means rear village) and decided to head to <a href="/mountain-excursion/25-Sunnegga" class="lnks" target="_blank">Sunnegga</a>,our next scenic viewing spot for the Matterhorn and the surrounding mountains. </p>
                                        <p>The Sunnegga-Rothorn valley station is a comfortable 10-minute walk away from Zermatt train station. </p>
                                        <p>Just hop on to the funicular that takes you to the top in under 5 minutes.There is a Wolli Adventure park by the lake where kids can cool off and have some fun for families with little kids.</p>
                                        <p>Of course,the main reason to be here was the view of the Matterhorn,and we were truly rewarded with that! </p>
                                        <p>A perfect way to end the second day of our 6 days in Switzerland. </p>
                                        <div class="bdm-bookCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-left">
                                                <img src="/images/Mountains/Matterhorn-Glacier-Paradise-medium2.webp" alt="">
                                            </div>
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-right">
                                                <p class="bookButton">Matterhorn Glacier Paradise</p>
                                                <a href="/mountain-excursion/7-matterhorn-glacier-paradise" class="bordered-btn gray" target="_blank">Book Now</a>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="4">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Day 3: Zermatt to Interlaken</h2>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/grindelwald.jpg" alt="grindelwald" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>A hugely popular Swiss town for tourists and a base for many sightseeing options and activities – this is Interlaken.</p>
                                        <p>A 2.30-hour train journey with 2 changes brought us into Interlaken by lunchtime.We had the option of taking an apartment but decided to go with a hotel to cover breakfast.There are a lot of hotels close to both Interlaken East and West stations.</p>
                                        <p>Not knowing how much we could cover on this day,we had only booked a <a href="/mountain-excursion/19-jetboat-interlaken" class="lnks" target="_blank">jetboat in Interlaken ride.</a></p>
                                        <p>We were picked up from our hotel and taken to the jetty.All geared up with life jackets, we were ready for our ride along with another few passengers in the same boat. </p>
                                        <p>Zooming at high speed with 360-degree spins in the shimmering lake surrounded by stunning green mountains was really an experience.Later, we headed back to Interlaken and spent the evening in town walking around the main street – Hoheweg.</p>
                                        <p>However,if you wish and have enough energy left,you can ascend to <a href="/mountain-excursion/2-harder-kulm" class="lnks" target="_blank">Harder Kulm</a> to indulge in one of the most breathtaking views of Interlaken from atop.A funicular railway that’s more than 100 years old takes you on the cliff at 1322 m above sea level.</p>
                                        <p>On top,bask in the astounding view of Interlaken and Switzerland's three most popular mountains – Eiger,Monch,andJungfraujoch.Many people include Harder Kulm in their <a href="/switzerland-tour-packages" class="lnks" target="_blank">Switzerland tour package</a> as it doesn’t take much time.</p>
                                        <p>That pretty much will sum up your itinerary on day 4.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-bookCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-left">
                                                <img src="/images/Mountains/Harder-Kulm-small.webp" alt="">
                                            </div>
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-right">
                                                <p class="bookButton">Harder Kulm</p>
                                                <a href="/mountain-excursion/2-harder-kulm" class="bordered-btn gray" target="_blank">Book Now</a>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="5">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Day 4: Interlaken - Jungfrau</h2>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/ice-palace-jungfraujoch.jpg" alt="ice palace jungfraujoch" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>One of the main reasons for the popularity of Interlaken is the Jungfrau. A visit to Jungfraujoch starts from Interlaken Ost station. When we visited, there was just one route to follow. But as of the end of 2020, there is a new route which takes you by cable car part of the way. One can now choose from one of the 2 routes to the top of <a href="/mountain-excursion/1-jungfraujoch-top-of-europe" class="lnks" target="_blank">Jungfrau - Top of Europe.</a>This is the highest train station in Europe! </p>
                                        <h3>Route 1 – The original route. Train only</h3>
                                        <p>We exchanged our Jungfrau tickets at the counter at Interlaken Ost station and started our journey. With 2 train changes at Lauterbrunnen and Kleine Scheidegg, we were at the peak station in roughly 2.10 hours. </p>
                                        <p>The route is very scenic, and on the last journey, the train stops a couple of times for people to get off for a few minutes and enjoy the views of the glacier, take photos and also get acclimatized to the height. </p>
                                        <h3>Route 2 – The new route. Train and Cableway</h3>
                                        <p>This route goes from Interlaken Ost to Grindelwald by train, then by cable car to the new Eigergletscher station and then again by train to the peak.  A person saves roughly 40 to 50 minutes on this route. Hopefully, we will do this the next time we are in Switzerland</p>
                                        <p>Jungfrau is snowbound throughout the year. So, we decided to have some fun in the snow and then went to see the Ice Palace and have a bite at one of the restaurants. Before leaving, we went to the Lindt Chocolate Heaven, and no one can be faulted for going overboard. </p>
                                        <p>On the way back down, we had a choice of visiting Grindelwald or the Trummelbach Falls from Interlaken. We decided on the latter since we had heard so much about these glacial waterfalls. </p>
                                        <p>On reaching Lauterbrunnen, we took a bus which takes you close to the falls. There is a lift that transports you up into the mountain, and from there, there is a series of steps and pathways that allow you to get different views of the chilly falls. These falls are actually caused by the melting waters of the Jungfrau, Eiger and Monch mountains. There is a nominal fee to enter, but we were delighted we visited. </p>
                                        <p>This day was the best day in our 6 days <a href="/blog/switzerland-itinerary-8-days" class="lnks" target="_blank">Switzerland itinerary.</a></p>
                                        <div class="bdm-bookCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-left">
                                                <img src="/images/blog/jungfraujoch.png" alt=" Jungfraujoch included in budget trip to Switzerland">
                                            </div>
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-right">
                                                <p class="bookButton">Jungfrau</p>
                                                <a href="/mountain-excursion/1-jungfraujoch-top-of-europe" class="bordered-btn gray">Book Now</a>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="6">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Day 5: Interlaken – Aletsch Arena</h2>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/aletsch-arena.jpg" alt="aletsch-arena" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>The Aletsch Glacier is the largest in Europe. To get a great view of this sea of ice, we visited the <a href="/mountain-excursion/36-aletsch-arena" class="lnks" target="_blank">Aletsch Arena.</a></p>
                                        <p>A train ride of 1.30 hours transported us to the Betten valley-station. From there, we took the cable car to the car-free village of Bettmeralp. After a short exploration of the village with its lovely chapel and lake, we continued by gondola to the Bettmerhorn. </p>
                                        <p>At the peak, there is a viewing platform from where you get stunning views. The Aletsch Glacier is 23 kms long, listed under the UNESCO World Heritage Site and holds around 11 billion tonnes of ice. </p>
                                        <p>With exhilarating views of 4000m peaks including Matterhorn, Jungfrau and Mont Blanc (Europe’s highest mountain, located in France) the Aletsch Arena was a real treat.There are a couple of other points from which you can reach the peak, but from Interlaken, we thought this was convenient. </p>
                                        <p>Depending on the season, there are various activities offered on top. Try your hand (or elgs) on a Glacier Walk, toboggan run, skiing, or even yoga. </p>
                                        <p>We spent some time in the interactive museum “Glacier World” at the Bettmerhorn. </p>
                                        <p>On our way back, we decided to stop by Brig for a quick tour of the town. Brig is home to the stunning Stockalper Palace and grounds. You can take guided tours to learn the history of this structure built between 1658 and 1678. </p>
                                        <p>And with that our second last day of 6 days in Switzerland came to an end. </p>
                                        <div class="bdm-bookCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-left">
                                                <img src="/images/Mountains/Aletsch-Arena-Interlaken-medium3.webp" alt="">
                                            </div>
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-right">
                                                <p class="bookButton">Aletsch Arena</p>
                                                <a href="/mountain-excursion/36-aletsch-arena" class="bordered-btn gray" target="_blank">Book Now</a>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="7">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Day 6: Interlaken – Zurich</h2>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/rhine-falls.jpg" alt="aletsch-arena" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>An early start by train got us into Zurich via Bern in 2 hours. We had an evening flight, so we pretty much had the full day to spend it visiting the Rhine Falls. </p>
                                        <p>After leaving our luggage at the lockers at the lower level of the Zurich main station, we took the train to Neuhausen Rheinfall station and then reached the falls. </p>
                                        <p>We walked along the falls and then took the lift,which takes you to a level from where you can really feel the thunder of the falls.There is a nominal fee of Swiss Francs 5 per person for the falls.</p>
                                        <p>You can also take a boat ride to the centre of the falls and climb up to its centre's huge rock formation.We decided to give this a skip.There are various boat ride options,and they cost between 10 to 15 Swiss francs. </p>
                                        <p>On return to Zurich, we collected our luggage and headed to the airport. We wanted to reach the airport early to do some shopping. </p>
                                        <p>Instead of buying things and carrying them around, we stock up at the huge Migros grocery at the airport just before boarding the flight. </p>
                                        <p>Zurich airport has a huge selection of outlets. All kinds of watches, jewellery, apparel, sports brands, chocolates and more are available. </p>
                                        <p>Well this brings us to the end of our 6 days Switzerland itinerary.</p>
                                        <p>While we agree that it may seem a bit fast-paced for some; we definitely tried to make the most of every minute that we had, and it was so worth it! </p>

                                        <span>Travel tips:</span>
                                        <ul>
                                            <li>-  Keep in mind that your best travel companion for Switzerland is the Swiss Travel Pass. Mountains, museums and all kinds of public transport are at your fingertips, thanks to this pass</li>
                                            <li>-     Mountains like the Matterhorn and Jungfrau are snow-clad all year round. Carrying a jacket, sturdy pair of shoes and goggles is wise. </li>
                                            <li>-    If you think that the thinner air at the peak may make you woozy or light-headed, chew on some sour sweets en route to the top. </li>
                                            <li>-   Switzerland is fairly small. If you think checking in and out of hotels and moving from place to place is not for you, you can even base your stay in just one central place, such as Interlaken or Lucerne, and cover the country from there.</li>
                                        </ul>
                                    </li>
                                </ul>
                            </div>

                            <%--Switzerland-Itinerary-10-days--%>
                            <div class="bd-padding" id="divSwitzerland_Itinerary_10_days" runat="server" visible="false">
                                <ul>
                                    <li class="in-view">
                                        <p>
                                            Most people wonder why a country as tiny as Switzerland can warrant a stay of more than a couple of days. However, once you figure out the wealth of things that this little country offers, even a 10-day trip will seem too short. Trust me, I have done multiple <a href="/switzerland-tour-packages" class="lnks" target="_blank">trips to Switzerland</a>, increasing the duration of my stay each time and highly recommend a <a href="/blog/switzerland-itinerary-10-days" class="lnks" target="_blank">10 days in Switzerland</a>.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            This paradise of a country offers so much from tiny traditional villages to big vibrant cities, pristine lakes and snow-capped mountains filled with adventure and fun. You may not be able to cover it all at one go, but you can definitely try to pack in the best of it in around 10 days. Let me start with a summary of my recommendation for this:
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Day 1: Lucerne - Arrive Zurich and travel to Lucerne. Explore Lucerne.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Day 2: Lucerne - Travel to Engelberg and visit Mount Titlis with the world’s first revolving cable car.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Day 3: Interlaken - Travel to Interlaken and visit Jungfraujoch- Top of Europe.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Day 4: Interlaken - Experience the Golden Pass Line to Gstaad and Montreux.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Day 5: Zermatt - Travel to Zermatt and visit the Matterhorn Glacier Paradise.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Day 6: Zermatt - Explore Zermatt, visit Sunnegga Paradise, Gorner Gorge and Hinterdorf area.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Day 7: St Moritz - Travel to St Moritz on the slowest Express train - Glacier Express.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Day 8: Lugano -  Travel to Lugano via Tirano on the train and bus combination of the Bernina Express.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Day 9: Lugano - Take a day trip to Lake Como and Bellagio in Italy.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Day 10: Depart - Travel to Zurich  or Milan for flight home or onward journey.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            First things first; it would be best to arrive with a pre-purchased <a href="/swiss-travel-pass" class="lnks" target="_blank">Swiss Travel Pass</a> so that you can directly hop on to a train from the Zurich airport train station without having to wait in line to buy tickets or passes when all you want to do is head for your destination after a long flight.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Keep in mind that local travel in Switzerland is quite pricey. The pass covers all public transport, gives discounts on mountain trips, gives free entrance to museums, and is totally free for kids under 16!
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Let's get cracking with our 10-day program.
                                        </p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="1">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Day 1: Zurich - Lucerne</h2>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/lion-monument-lucerne.jpg" alt="Lion Monument Lucerne" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>
                                            Arrive in Zurich and hop on a train for Lucerne, which takes roughly 1.15 hours. Your day will depend on your arrival time in Lucerne. Here are some of the options for <a href="/blog/10-things-to-do-in-lucerne-switzerland" class="lnks" target="_blank">things to do in Lucerne today:</a>
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Option 1: <a href="/mountain-excursion/35-swiss-transport-museum" class="lnks" target="_blank">Swiss Transport Museum</a><br />
                                            Apart from showcasing the history of air, land, and even space transport, this open-air museum has a huge open arena where kids can try their hand at various activities. The complex also houses a planetarium, the country’s largest cinema screen, and the popular Swiss Chocolate Adventure. This is justifiably Switzerland’s most visited museum. The museum is partly open-air, so it would be wise to check the weather before heading there. It's a really fun family place where you can easily spend way over half a day.<br />
                                            Note: Make sure to flash your Swiss Travel Pass to avail of the <a href="/blog/top-discounts-on-swiss-travel-pass" class="lnks" target="_blank">Swiss Travel Pass discount</a> on the entrance fees.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Option 2: Local City Tour<br />
                                            If you would rather take it slow today, you can set off for a walk around this lovely town at your own pace.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Start with crossing the Chapel Bridge, read the history of this city and indeed one of Switzerland’s most iconic attractions. Continue to the Old Town with its winding cobbled-stone streets, timber-framed houses, Old Town Hall,  14th-century clock tower and Lucerne's oldest church, St. Peter's Chapel. Continue to another iconic attraction -the famous Lion Monument. From here, you can make your way back along the lakeside promenade, stopping by one or more of the many local chocolatiers before going back to your hotel.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Option 3: Mount Pilatus<br />
                                            If you have almost the whole day in hand, visit one of the nearby mountains. <a href="/mountain-excursion/6-mount-pilatus" class="lnks" target="_blank">Mount Pilatus</a> would be a good choice. The Golden Round Trip offered on this mountain makes the travel as exciting as the peak.<br />
                                            Head to the Lucerne jetty (conveniently located opposite the main train station) and hop on the boat to Alpnachstad. (This journey is free as it is public transport and part of the Swiss Travel Pass.)
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            At Alpnachstad, get off the boat, head to the cogwheel train (the steepest in the world), and proceed to Mount Pilatus. On the way back use the cable car down to Kriens and take the bus back to Lucerne. If you still have time upon your return, carry on with your exploration of this lakeside town.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Note: Like most mountains, Mount Pilatus offers a Swiss Travel Pass discount. However, you must make a minimally charged reservation if you are travelling on the cogwheel train, which runs between May and November.
                                        </p>
                                        <div class="bdm-bookCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-left">
                                                <img src="/images/Mountains/Mount-Pilatus-medium2.webp" alt="Mount Pilatus">
                                            </div>
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-right">
                                                <p class="bookButton">Mount Pilatus</p>
                                                <a href="/mountain-excursion/6-mount-pilatus" class="bordered-btn gray" target="_blank">Book Now</a>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="2">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Day 2: Lucerne – Mount Titlis</h2>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/mount-titlis.jpg" alt="Mount Titlis" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>
                                            You won't want to miss Mount Titlis while staying in Lucerne. To visit Mount Titlis, take a train from Lucerne train station to Engelberg (45 minutes), a beautiful little  Swiss village located at the base of Mount Titlis.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            From here, walk for 15 minutes or take a bus to the cable car valley station for Titlis. Start your journey by two cable cars (including the revolving cable car – Titlis Rotair) to reach the top with mesmerising views of the Swiss Alps.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            On top, enjoy various activities like the Ice Flyer Chairlift, the Ice Cave and the amazing Titlis Cliff Walk. Have lunch at one of the restaurants at the peak before your descent.<br />
                                            Try making it back to Engelberg with some time to spare so you can walk around the village before returning to Lucerne.
                                        </p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="3">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Day 3: Lucerne – Interlaken – Jungfraujoch</h2>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/interlaken-switzerland-itinerary.jpg" alt="Interlaken Switzerland Itinerary" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>
                                            After covering all or most of the attractions in Lucerne, you can move on to another amazing Swiss town. Get ready for Interlaken, home to the majestic <a href="/mountain-excursion/1-jungfraujoch-top-of-europe" class="lnks" target="_blank">Jungfraujoch -the top of Europe</a>.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            To do this excursion today, it would be nice to depart Lucerne around 7 to 8 am and hop on to the famous Interlaken - Lucerne Express, which connects these two towns. The journey to Interlaken takes roughly 2 hours. Arrive, check in to your Interlaken hotel or apartment and get ready to head off to the top of Europe!
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            There are two ways to reach this mountain - the older traditional route or the new cable car route via Grindelwald.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Route 1<br />
                                            The traditional route takes around 2 hours and takes you from Interlaken Ost station to the peak via 2 changes in Lauterbrunnen and Kleine Scheidegg.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            The route is very scenic, and on the last journey, the train stops a couple of times at viewing points that give breathtaking views of the glacier. These little photo stops also help you to get acclimatized to the rarer air as you ascend.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            <u>Route 2</u><br />
                                            The new route (started in 2020) takes you from Interlaken Ost to Grindelwald by train. At Grindelwald, you switch to the cable car to reach the Eiger Glacier Station. Then again, switch to train to reach the peak. This route takes roughly 1.15 hours.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            The Jungfrau excursion is one of the more expensive ones, so make sure you have your <a href="/blog/10-ultimate-benefits-of-swiss-travel-pass" class="lnks" target="_blank">Swiss Travel Pass</a> so that you get the almost 35% discount for pass holders.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            At the top, enjoy amazing views of the Aletsch Glacier, the longest in the Alps.<br />
                                            Enjoy the ice palace with its sculptures, experience snow fun in the snow park in the summer and give in to temptation at the Lindt Chocolate Heaven.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            On the way back down, you can stop at Grindelwald and visit this Alpine village or stop at Lauterbrunnen and visit another attraction of this region—the glacial Trummelbach Falls.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            The falls can be reached by a 10-minute bus ride from Lauterbrunnen station.
	The Trummelbach falls are actually 10 thundering waterfalls inside the mountain and are reached via a lift.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Note: Kids under four are not allowed to visit the falls.
                                        </p>
                                        <div class="bdm-bookCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-left">
                                                <img src="/images/blog/jungfraujoch.png" alt=" Jungfraujoch included in budget trip to Switzerland" />
                                            </div>
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-right">
                                                <p class="bookButton">Jungfrau</p>
                                                <a href="/mountain-excursion/1-jungfraujoch-top-of-europe" class="bordered-btn gray" target="_blank">Book Now</a>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="4">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Day 4: Interlaken – Gstaad and Montreux</h2>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/chillon-castle-boat-montreux.jpg" alt="Interlaken Switzerland Itinerary" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>
                                            The most idyllic pictures of Switzerland are likely shot in Gstaad. Going to Gstaad gives you one more opportunity to use your Swiss Travel Pass on a scenic train. The Golden Pass Line connecting these towns will get you into Gstaad in roughly 1.50 hours via some of the most picturesque terrain.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            The beauty of Gstaad has lured the rich and famous to holiday there and also made many leave their homes to settle there permanently. The perfect little wooden chalets in a manicured setting remind you of a scene from a fairy tale.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            After exploring this town, you can proceed further by train to Montreux (1.35 hours), a beautiful village on the shores of Lake Geneva. Spend some time walking along the lakeside promenade, visit the statue of Freddie Mercury and the Chillon Castle. The castle is built on an outcrop on the shores of Lake Geneva and is the most visited historical building in Switzerland.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            In the evening, proceed back to Interlaken (2.15 hours).
                                        </p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="5">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Day 5: Interlaken – Zermatt</h2>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/photogallery/Matterhorn6.webp" alt="Matterhorn" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>
                                            Travel to Zermatt (2.10 hours), the most popular car-free village and a famous ski resort. There are many <a href="/blog/11-things-to-do-in-zermatt" class="lnks" target="_blank">things to do in Zermatt</a>, but the main attraction is the Matterhorn.<br />
                                            Settle into your hotel and proceed to the <a href="/mountain-excursion/7-matterhorn-glacier-paradise" class="lnks" target="_blank">Matterhorn Glacier Paradise</a> to get the best views of the Matterhorn. Walk through the village to reach the cable car base station. Flash your Swiss Travel Pass to avail of the passholder discount or exchange your pre-purchased voucher and get going.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            The ride up is as beautiful as the view from below.  Spend some time getting the perfect photos, visit the ice palace, and have a hearty Swiss meal with a view before you head back down. If you are up for it, you can also continue on the new alpine crossing, which takes you all the way to Cervina in Italy! If you are celebrating a big day or feel like splurging, go all out and book a Swarovski car. Embellished with Swarovski crystals on the outside and a glass-bottomed floor, these cars can elevate your experience to new heights!
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Note: Zermatt is a car-free village. If you have a hotel that is far from the station, make sure you call ahead and check if they offer complimentary or paid pick-ups.
                                        </p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="6">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Day 6: Zermatt</h2>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Mountains/Sunnegga-Matterhorn-medium1.webp" alt="Sunnegga Matterhorn" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>
                                            Soak in the atmosphere of this typical Swiss village today. Just walk along the village centre with its numerous souvenir shops, cafes and boutiques.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            You can visit the Matterhorn museum, which gives you an insight into the village's history and houses original objects from the first ascent of the Matterhorn.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Visit the Gorner Gorge (summer only) at the south end of the village and explore the breathtaking beauty of this narrow river gorge while walking across it on an elevated wooden walkway suspended over stunning rock formations and turquoise waters.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Wander along the Hinterdorf, Zermatt’s unique old town with centuries-old structures.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            If you still crave the perfect shot of the mighty Matterhorn massif, visit another vantage point - Sunnegga Paradise, a popular viewing point for the Matterhorn. With a relatively quick ascent (under 5 minutes) and fun stuff like the Wolli Adventure Park and a Marmot trail, the Sunnegga Paradise is a popular family activity.
                                        </p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="7">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Day 7: Zermatt – St. Moritz</h2>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/photogallery/GlacierExpress4.webp" alt="Glacier Express" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>
                                            All aboard! Embark on what is said to be the most beautiful train journey in the world – The Glacier Express. This journey will take you from the west of Switzerland to St. Moritz in the east. Known as the ‘slowest express train’, this narrow-gauge journey progresses at around 24 mph. It takes you through spectacular scenery, 291 bridges, 91 tunnels, deep gorges, and hair-raising Viaducts.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            In St. Moritz, you will have arrived at one of the world’s most sought-after winter destinations. It offers some of the best ski slopes in the world, attracting leisure travellers and sports enthusiasts alike. With a beautiful lake, great spas, and exclusive hotels, this little town offers all the glitz and glamour one can wish for.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            The Glacier Express requires a mandatory seat reservation, and one of the <a href="/blog/10-ultimate-benefits-of-swiss-travel-pass" class="lnks" target="_blank">benefits of Swiss Travel Pass</a> is that one can get these at special rates. Remember to book your seats well in advance as they tend to sell out soon. Other than the first and second class, this train also offers an <a href="/mountain-excursion/43-glacier-express" class="lnks" target="_blank">Excellence Class</a>, which offers all window seats, a multi-course meal, Swiss wines and more.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Note: Depending on the season, there are up to 3 Glacier Express departures in a day. The Glacier Express has a fully equipped restaurant, and meals can also be pre-booked.
                                        </p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="8">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Day 8: St. Moritz – Lugano</h2>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/photogallery/BerninaExpress3.webp" alt="Bernina Express" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>
                                            From a winter destination to one that has 300 days of sunshine a year…and that too on another scenic train!! Get ready for Mediterranean warmth as you board the Bernina Express, which will take you from St. Moritz to Lugano, passing through UNESCO World Heritage sites.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            The Bernina Express journey combines a train and bus segment. The first leg, from St. Moritz to Tirano, takes 2 hours and 15 minutes by train. The next part is via bus. The bus journey from Tirano to Lugano takes 3 hours and gets you into Lugano at around 5:30 in the evening.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            For both segments, a compulsory reservation is required, and it should be made well in advance since seats sell out soon. Swiss Travel Pass holders get special rates.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Note: While booking, pay attention to match the timings between train and bus connections.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            The ideal booking would be:<br />
                                            &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;-Depart St. Moritz at 9:17 am and arrive in Tirano at 11:32 am<br />
                                            &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;-Depart Tirano at 2:20 pm and arrive in Lugano at 5:30 pm<br />
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Note: Timings are subject to change and should be checked as per your travel date.
                                        </p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="9">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Day 9: Lugano – Lake Como</h2>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/lake-como.webp" alt="Lake Como" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>
                                            Venture into Italy today. Visit Lake Como, a picturesque and popular resort in Italy that can be reached via a direct train in just 45 minutes. Spend time walking around the lake, take a bus to Bellagio, known as the ‘Pearl of Lake Como’ or shop for silk, which this area is famous for. Return to Lugano in the evening.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Note: You will need to purchase a train ticket to visit Como since the Swiss Travel Pass is not valid for this journey.
                                        </p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="10">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Day 10: Lugano – Zurich or Lugano - Milan</h2>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/lake-zurich.webp" alt="Lake Zurich" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>
                                            Based on where you are ending your holiday, you can do one of the following today.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Option 1: - Zurich<br />
                                            Reach Zurich main station via a direct train (roughly 2 hours). If you have a late evening flight, you can leave your bags at the station and still make the most of this day by heading to the Rhine Falls - Europe’s largest falls, either on your own or via a guided tour. Take a boat ride to the centre of the falls or view it from one of the viewing points close enough to feel the spray and hear the thunder.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Alternatively, you can set off to explore the town on your own or hop on a guided tour, which will conveniently take you through all the best parts of this vibrant city.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Of course, if you have more time and are staying a couple of more nights, there are many other sights to see and things to do in Zurich.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Note: The Rhine Falls charges an entrance fee of roughly CHF 5 per person as it is a protected National Park. The boat ride will cost an additional CHF 8 to CHF 10 per person.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Option 2: - Milan<br />
                                            If you are departing from Milan airport, you will take a train to Malpensa airport (roughly 1.5 hours). You will have to purchase a train ticket since the Swiss Pass will not cover this journey.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Time permitting, you can get off at the main station and take a Hop-on-Hop-off bus tour to get a feel of the city.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Don’t forget your last-minute shopping. After all, you are in the fashion capital of the world!
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            As I said, Switzerland has so much to offer. The above are just some of the main things that one can do whilst maintaining a well-paced 10-day program. Hope you can include most or all of the above and more in your next  Swiss holiday program.
                                        </p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li class="in-view">
                                        <h3>Things to know:</h3>
                                        <p>
                                            The Swiss Travel Pass comes in versions of 3, 4, 8 and 15 days. There is also a continuous pass and a flex option, which allows you to travel the chosen number of days within a month (convenient for those staying in one place much longer than in others).<br />
                                            Switzerland is undoubtedly expensive when compared to the rest of Europe. To help with the budget, you can opt for <a href="/apartments" class="lnks" target="_blank">apartments in Switzerland</a> instead of hotels. Apartments can accommodate more people per unit and also have a kitchenette, which makes it comfortable to cook a few meals or have some grocery-bought meals instead of going to restaurants.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Restaurant meals can cost upwards of Swiss Francs 35 per person, whereas a quick pizza, McDonald's, or doner kebab meal can cost Swiss Francs 18-20.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            The best souvenirs to purchase would be a Swiss army knife, cowbells, chocolates, cheeses and, if your budget permits, Swiss watches!
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Never travel without a warm jacket, comfortable shoes, and sunglasses. Many mountains are snowbound throughout the year.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            Even though the Swiss Franc is the official currency, the Euro is accepted everywhere. Remember that even if you pay a Euro, change is always returned in Swiss Francs.<br />
                                            Euro coins are not accepted in most places. However, a few shops at the airport do.
                                        </p>
                                    </li>
                                </ul>
                            </div>

                                        <p>Are you a leisure traveller or a thrill seeker? Doesn’t matter, TITLIS has got all your needs covered!From mountain biking to rowing and everything in between, TITLIS offers a great range of summer activities for all age groups. SWISStours' travel consultants have curated a list of summer activities you must do if you are visiting TITLIS.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-bookCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-left">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/titlis-rotair.jpg?ver=1" alt="">
                                            </div>

                                                <a href="/mountain-excursion/5-mount-titlis" class="bordered-btn gray" target="_blank">Book Now</a>

                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">1. Hiking</h2>
                                        <p>For the average walker or a professional hiker, TITLIS has seven beautiful trails that take you through unreal landscapes that you can only dream of. From trails as short as an hour to as long as 16 hours, you can take your pick and come back wanting more.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/titlis-hiking.jpg" alt="switzerland itinerary peak Matterhorn" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <h3>The Engelberg-Untertrübsee-Trübsee</h3>
                                        <p>The trail takes you via Stapfmatti to Untertrübsee, starting from Engelberg. Many feel the trail ends too soon and prefer to continue on the route to Obertrübsee on foot. Leisure buffs can simply hop on the Älplerseil cable car. Once at Obertrübsee, you can follow the Trübsee alpine flower trail to Trübsee middle station and check out their fun and thrilling activities.</p>
                                        <table class="table table-bordered">
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Walking time</th>
                                                <td>3 hours</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Height</th>
                                                <td>1,000–1,796 metres </td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Level</th>
                                                <td>Moderate</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Accessible</th>
                                                <td>June to October</td>
                                            </tr>
                                        </table>
                                        <br />
                                        <h3>Waterfall Loop</h3>
                                        <p>A circular walk called the Waterfall Loop starts at the Trübsee play area and takes you to the Stäubi waterfall, where the cold water from the Steinberg glacier pours down the mountain. You may sit down and take in the beautiful views of Trübsee at the peak and the waterfall.</p>
                                        <p>On warmer days, a stroll by the cool, invigorating glacier water is extremely delightful. You will find lovely, protected alpine flora above the waterfall.</p>
                                        <table class="table table-bordered">
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Walking time</th>
                                                <td>1 hour</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Height</th>
                                                <td>1,769 – 1,916 metres</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Level</th>
                                                <td>Moderate</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Accessible</th>
                                                <td>July to October</td>
                                            </tr>
                                        </table>
                                        <br />
                                        <h3>Trübsee Circular Trail</h3>
                                        <p>This trail is for individuals and families who prefer a more leisurely flat stroll or for those with pushchairs, the path around Trübsee Lake is a lovely walk. There are four firepits along the route where you may stop for a snack and enjoy the great outdoors - don't forget to carry some sausages.</p>
                                        <table class="table table-bordered">
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Walking time</th>
                                                <td>1 hour</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Height</th>
                                                <td>1,769 metres</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Level</th>
                                                <td>Easy</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Accessible</th>
                                                <td>All Seasons</td>
                                            </tr>
                                        </table>
                                        <br />
                                        <h3>The "Murmeliwanderung" or Marmot path</h3>
                                        <p>This path is also known as the Trübsee-Jochpasslift-Jochpass-Schaftal-Tannalp-Engstlenalp-Jochpass-Jochpasslift-Trübsee route. There are adorable tiny rodents that are easy to spot if you bring a pair of binoculars. If you're really fortunate, you could even see an ibex or chamois in the area.</p>
                                        <p>The trailhead is the mountain station at Trübsee. Stick to the lakeside route and then take the chairlift up to Jochpass. Continue on in Schaftal's direction from here.</p>
                                        <p>On the journey to Engstlenalp, the breathtaking alpine panorama that surrounds the deep-blue Engstlensee lake is likely to captivate your attention.</p>
                                        <table class="table table-bordered" width="100%">
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Walking time</th>
                                                <td>5 hours</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Height</th>
                                                <td>1,769 – 2,222 metres</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Level</th>
                                                <td>Easy</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Accessible</th>
                                                <td>June to October</td>
                                            </tr>
                                        </table>
                                        <br />
                                        <h3>4 Lakes Hike</h3>
                                        <p>The Engleberg-Trübsee-Jochpass-Engstlenalp-Tannalp-Melchsee-Frutt hike, popularly known as the 4 Lakes Hike, will introduce you to one of Central Switzerland's most stunning regions. To get to the Jochpass chair lift, take the cable car to Trübsee and then stroll along the lake. </p>
                                        <p>After reaching the summit, the route continues to Melchsee-Frutt through Engstlenalp and Tannalp. Drop off at Stöckalp using the cable car, then board the Postbus to Sarnen. You can return to Engelberg via train from here. </p>
                                        <table class="table table-bordered" width="100%">
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Walking time</th>
                                                <td>4 hours(Trübsee to Melchsee-Frutt)</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Height</th>
                                                <td>1,769 – 1,920 metres</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Level</th>
                                                <td>Moderate</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Accessible</th>
                                                <td>June to October</td>
                                            </tr>
                                        </table>
                                        <br />
                                        <h3>Geology Trail</h3>
                                        <p>You may discover a great deal about the geology of the Alps on the Geology Trail from Trübsee to Stand. The steep panoramic walk from Trübsee mountain station to Stand gives breathtaking views down into a fascinating glacial world, while information boards offer insight into the geological development of the TITLIS region. With its breathtaking views, this walk is simply stunning.</p>
                                        <table class="table table-bordered" width="100%">
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Walking time</th>
                                                <td>2 hours</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Height</th>
                                                <td>1,769 – 2,430 metres</td>
                                            </tr>

                                                <th>Level</th>
                                                <td>Moderate</td>
                                            </tr>

                                                <td>June to September</td>
                                            </tr>

                                        <h3>Alpine Cheese Trail</h3>
                                        <p>Around Engelberg, the Alpine Cheese Trail links eight Alpine dairies. These dairy farms may well be found in Langenboden, Untertrübsee, Gerschnialp, Stäfeli, Blackenalp, Steinäbnet, and Surenen.</p>
                                        <p>There are numerous Alpine dairy farms in the TITLIS, Fürenalp, and Brunni regions. This cheesy hike can even be completed in parts.</p>
                                        <table class="table table-bordered" width="100%">
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Walking time</th>

                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">2.Trübsee Adventure</h2>
                                        <p>Did you ever want to experience how it felt like to do your own stunts? The Trübsee Adventure will make your wishes come true!</p>
                                        <p>The adventure consists of four activities – The BagJumo Tower, Trampoline2Bag, Slackline and Bouncy Castle. Guess what? They are all free of charge with guides present all the time.</p>

You can count on the TITLIS Adventure Park guides to assist you with your initial jumps.</p>

By the terrace in front of Lago Torbido is where you'll find the distinctive Rotair bouncy castle. On the terrace of Trübsee Alpine Lodge, children can also jump around on the trampoline with a net and Alpine hut bounce house.</p>

                                    <li data-index="4">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">4. Mountain Biking</h2>
                                        <p>TITLIS has it all, from a downhill free-wheel or a sporty thrill on a singletrack. </p>
                                        <p>Around Trübsee, there are a lot of leisurely trails that are suitable for families. You can ride your bike up to the top in comfort with TITLIS Cableways. </p>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/titlis-mountain-biking.jpg" alt="switzerland itinerary peak Matterhorn" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="5">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Engelberg-Untertrübsee- Trübsee Trail</h2>
                                        <p>When leaving the valley and heading to Trübsee middle station, this journey will take you over uneven terrain. You can take the Älplerseil lift to travel a portion of the route if you don't feel like going the entire way. Then, you can travel from Untertrübsee to Obertrübsee by cable car. </p>
                                        <table class="table table-bordered" width="100%">
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Distance</th>
                                                <td>13km</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Altitude Difference</th>
                                                <td>830m</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Level</th>
                                                <td>Challenging (for seasoned bikers only)</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Accessible</th>
                                                <td>June to October</td>
                                            </tr>
                                        </table>
                                        <br />
                                        <h3>Trudy Trail</h3>
                                        <p>The Jochpass-Trübsee mountain bike route connects Jochpass with Trübsee station below. It is commonly known as the "Trudy trail" in honour of the hut warden at Jochpass. </p>
                                        <p>There are a lot of challenging sections, sharp twists, and hurdles along the path, but no difficult steps or leaps. For those who enjoy downhill riding, this route is ideal. </p>
                                        <table class="table table-bordered" width="100%">
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Distance</th>
                                                <td>1km</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Altitude Difference</th>
                                                <td>210m</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Level</th>
                                                <td>Challenging (for seasoned bikers only)</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Accessible</th>
                                                <td>July to October</td>
                                            </tr>
                                        </table>
                                        <br />
                                        <h3>Jochopass Trail</h3>
                                        <p>The new Jochpass trail, which runs from Jochpass to Trübsee, was created as a recreational route for both inexperienced and seasoned bikers alike. Different speeds can be used to navigate the hurdles and bends. </p>
                                        <table class="table table-bordered" width="100%">
                                            <tr>
                                                <th>Distance</th>
                                                <td>4.5km</td>
                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>

                                            </tr>
                                            <tr>

                                                <td>Moderate (prior mountain biking experience required)</td>
                                            </tr>
