                                    <li data-index="2">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Cruises on Lakes Thun and Brienz - Interlaken</h2>
                                        <p>The town of Interlaken lies between the two beautiful lakes Thun and Brienz. Regular ferries operate along the lakes, which you can board with the Swiss Travel Pass. </p>
                                        <p>The Lake Brienz ferries run between the towns of Interlaken and Brienz, passing by the picturesque Giessbach Falls and other cities like Iseltwald (made famous in the series Crash Landing on You) and Bonigen, where you can disembark and then continue on the next ferry. </p>
                                        <p>The ferry docks are conveniently located near the train stations (in Interlaken, it is close to Interlaken Ost station), making it easy to take a one-way ferry and return via train.Although the ferries typically operate from March through December, there are more services available during the summer and fall (May through October) than in the other months.</p>
                                        <p>At Brienz, you can ride the <a href="/mountain-excursion/61-brienz-rothorn-bahn" class="lnks" target="_blank">Brienzer Rothorn Bahn</a>. The journey is made via a historic steam engine that pushes the carriages on a cogwheel railway to a height of 2244 metres, where you get rewarded with gorgeous views over the lake and the Bernese Oberland region.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/Cruise-Ship-at-Lake-Brienz.webp" alt="A white cruise ship sailing through Lake Brienz that one can ride with the Swiss Travel Pass, highlighting that it is one of the Hidden Gems with Swiss Travel Pass" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>In Interlaken, you can combine the cruise with a ride up to the picturesque <a target="_blank" href="/mountain-excursion/2-harder-kulm" class='lnks'>Harder Kulm</a> and enjoy a meal with a beautiful view over the lakes, especially at sunset.</p>
                                        <p>The Lake Thun ferries operate between the towns of Interlaken and Thun, with numerous stops at smaller cities like Spiez. The docks at both Thun and Interlaken West are close to the train stations.</p>
                                        <p>The ferries operate year-round, with the highest frequency between May and October.You can also combine the cruise with some fun time at <a href="/adventure-tours/ropes-park-interlaken/?id=act_b5fed750-eb80-4584-987d-1b9d8acf8eec" class="lnks" target="_blank">Ropes Park Interlaken</a>  and try your hand at the rope bridges, ziplines, and Tarzan swings. There are 14 courses of varying difficulty, which are fun for all ages, including toddlers.</p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="3">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Rigi-Queen of the Mountains- Lucerne</h2>
                                        <p>Mount Rigi, affectionately known as the Queen of the Mountains, is located east of Lucerne and is one of the few mountains that are completely free with the Swiss Travel Pass. At 1800 metres, it is at a lower elevation than other central mountains, but it still boasts a stunning scenic beauty.</p>
                                        <p>With different approaches from various locations (Arth Goldau, Vitznau, and Weggis), Mt. Rigi offers stunning views of lakes and lush, flower-bedecked pastures.</p>
                                        <p>At the peak, you can walk along a path to the fenced-in viewing area for great views, visit the chapel called Regina Montium (Queen of the mountains), and even climb the weather tower to get a different perspective of the view.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/Rigi-winter-hikers.webp" alt="Two hikers hiking through the Rigi Mountain in the winter, it is considered one of the Hidden Gems with Swiss Travel Pass" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>

                                        <p>Either along the ascent or descent, you can visit Rigi Kaltbad, famous for its excellent spa, and pamper yourself with some me-time in one of the pools whilst looking out over the surrounding landscape.</p>
                                        <p>You can combine a half-day at Mt. Rigi with another popular Lucerne activity, such as the <a href="/en-in/mountain-excursion/34-saphir-panoramic-yacht-cruise" class="lnks" target="_blank">Saphir Panoramic Yacht Cruise</a>  on Lake Lucerne.</p>

                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="4">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Swiss Museum of Transport - Lucerne</h2>
                                        <p>Another gem in Lucerne, the <a href="/en-in/mountain-excursion/35-swiss-transport-museum" class="lnks" target="_blank">Swiss Museum of Transport </a>(Verkehrshaus der Schweiz) opened in 1959 and remains the most visited museum in Switzerland to this day. In addition to showcasing the past, present, and future of various forms of mobility (air, land, water & space), the museum also features several unique themed areas, promising a diverse and exciting experience for all visitors.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Mobility-themed areas</h3>
                                        <p>Car, train, aircraft, and even space enthusiasts can feast on the large number of historic and present-day models of vehicles, motorbikes, helicopters, train engines, and more, and even experience plane and helicopter simulators.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Planetarium</h3>
                                        <p>The planetarium offers immersive experiences that delve into the mysteries of the universe through state-of-the-art astronomical tours.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Filmtheatre</h3>
                                        <p>It features one of Switzerland’s largest IMAX screens and presents a diverse range of movies, documentaries, and live broadcasts of operas and ballets from around the world.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Swiss Chocolate Adventure</h3>
                                        <p>A 20-minute ride on a carriage passing by audio visuals that showcase the journey of chocolate from origin, production, and transportation, with a tasting station at the end.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Arena</h3>
                                        <p>A large outdoor area perfect for families, the Arena has a boating pool, play scooters and carts, a large playground area in the form of a construction zone, and places in which you can relax or have a snack.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Red Bull The Edge</h3>
                                        <p>A virtual reality experience that has you scaling the Matterhorn to an altitude of 4478 metres with great views from the summit.</p>
                                        <p>The Swiss Museum of Transport can also be a day trip from Interlaken. In fact, you can ride the scenic <a href="/mountain-excursion/56-luzern-interlaken-express" class="lnks" target="_blank">Lucerne-Interlaken Express</a> train (also included in the Swiss Travel Pass) to Lucerne. However, be sure to check seat availability and reserve them in advance if necessary.</p>
                                        <p><b>Note:</b> The Swiss Museum of Transport is discounted (not free) with the Swiss Travel Pass.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-bookCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-left">
                                                <img src="/images/Mountains/Swiss-Transport-Museum-medium3.webp" alt="" />
                                            </div>
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-right">
                                                <p class="bookButton">Swiss Transport Museum</p>
                                                <a href="/en-in/mountain-excursion/35-swiss-transport-museum" class="bordered-btn gray" target="_blank">Book Now</a>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="5">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Château de Chillon - Montreux</h2>
                                        <p>Perched on an outcrop on Lake Geneva, close to Montreux, is the Château de Chillon, Switzerland’s most visited historic building. It is a leisurely walk (around 4 km) or a short bus or train ride away from the centre of Montreux.</p>
                                        <p>Over the centuries, the castle has served many roles- armoury, fortress, prison, administrative centre, royal residence, and more.</p>
                                        <p>It has inspired writers and poets alike, who were all moved by its beauty, as well as its tales of suffering.  Lord Byron was inspired to write his famous poem, The Prisoner of Chillon, when he visited the dungeons in 1816.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">The Chapel of St George</h3>
                                        <p>Some consider the chapel to be the ‘jewel of Chillon’ with its vaulted Gothic ceiling and ornate decor.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Dungeons/Prisons</h3>
                                        <p>On the darker side, the history of the castle is replete with stories of how prisoners were chained, tortured, and starved in the cold underground dungeons. You can walk through these prison cells and see the worn stone pillars that still hold stories of the past.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Royal Residences</h3>
                                        <p>The Camera Domini (Lord’s bedroom) -decorated with 14th-century murals featuring animal motifs and the Camera Nova with its ceramic stove and striking oak wardrobe.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Archeological objects, weapons, and furniture</h3>
                                        <p>Almost 300 items, including objects from archeological digs, furniture like carved doors and chests, and weapons.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Great Halls and Courtyards</h3>
                                        <p>Large spaces that once hosted grand banquets and judicial proceedings.</p>
                                    </li>

                                    <li data-index="6">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Rhine Falls near Zurich</h2>
                                        <p>With a height of 23 metres and a width of 150 metres, the Rhine Falls are Europe’s largest waterfalls. The falls were formed over 15000 years ago at the end of the last Ice Age.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/People-admiring-Rhine-Falls.webp" alt="Two People admiring the majestic Rhine Falls, it can be easily considered as one of the Hidden Gems with Swiss Travel Pass" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>Hundreds of cubic metres of water crashing down over the 23 metres create a roar that is heard from miles away, and the mist often catches the sunlight in dazzling rainbows, giving it an ethereal glow.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Getting there</h3>
                                        <p>The Rhine Falls are conveniently reached via train from Zurich (or Zurich airport) with the help of the Swiss Travel Pass in two ways: either take the train to Schloss Laufen, which gets you to the Southern banks, or take the train to Neuhausen am Rheinfall, which gets you to the Northern banks.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">At the Falls</h3>
                                        <p>Take in the views of the falls from the viewing platforms (whilst being prepared to get sprayed by the mist). The platforms accessed via the south from Schloss Laufen am Rheinfall have a nominal fee, but get you really up close to the falls.</p>
                                        <p>The promenade views from the northern side (Neuhausen) are, however, free of charge.To get a different perspective, you can also walk along the pedestrian path on the rail bridge that crosses the river just above the falls.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Boat rides</h3>
                                        <p>From April to November, regular boat cruises are available for your choice. This is the best way to view the falls, as the boats take you right up close to them. One of the popular cruises is the Rock Tour, a 30-minute ride that takes you to the rock in the centre of the falls.</p>
                                        <p>You can disembark the boat here and climb up to the rock to get a 360-degree view of the falls from the viewing platform at the top. There are also various other cruises of different durations.</p>
                                        <p>You can combine a visit to the Rhine Falls with a visit to the medieval town of Stein Am Rhein, a city tour of Zurich, or an afternoon at the fantastic <a href="/mountain-excursion/47-lindt-chocolate" class="lnks" target="_blank">Lindt Home of Chocolate</a>.</p>
                                    </li>

                                    <li data-index="7">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Ballenberg Open Air Museum </h2>
                                        <p>Situated around 20 minutes from Brienz, Ballenberg Open Air Museum is a perfect family entertainment and learning experience.</p>
                                        <p>Spread over 66 hectares of landscaped and perfectly tended gardens and fields, the open-air museum features historical buildings, including farmhouses, cottages, and barns that have been carefully dismantled from their original locations and reconstructed here.</p>
                                        <p>Having started in 1978 with a modest 16 buildings, Ballenberg today boasts over 100 historical buildings.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">What to see and do:</h3>

                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Buildings</h3>
                                        <p>Walk through some of the buildings that include homes, barns, craftsmen’s dwellings, and granaries to get an idea of the building styles and materials used in the past. Kitchens, parlors, and sleeping areas provide insight into the daily life of the inhabitants.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Crafts</h3>
                                        <p>Gain insight into traditional crafts such as weaving, cheese making, carving, and the operation of old mills through live demonstrations and hands-on experiences.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Gardens and fields</h3>
                                        <p>Walk through the gardens and fields laid out in historically accurate styles. Learn about medicinal herbs, fruits, and vegetables used in traditional dishes.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Petting Zoo</h3>
                                        <p>The museum has over 200 farm animals. Kids can have a hands-on experience at the petting zoo, spend time in the playground, and enjoy the picnic areas.</p>
                                        <p>Brienz is just a 45-minute train ride from Interlaken and can be done as a half-day trip, combining it with any of the other <a href="/blog/things-to-do-in-interlaken" class="lnks" target="_blank">activities in Interlaken</a>.</p>
                                    </li>

                                    <li data-index="8">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">St Gallen Abbey Library</h2>
                                        <p>A sign over the entrance to the library reads “Psyches Iatreion”, which means “healing place for the soul”—an apt description as you enter Switzerland’s magnificent Baroque-Rococo treasure, the Abbey Library of St. Gallen. It is one of the oldest (built in 612, making it the third-oldest), richest, and most beautiful libraries in the world.</p>
                                        <p>It consists of 2 floors with a balcony running around the upper level. Built in the Rococo style, it has a rich, burnished wood panelling, curving forms, and exquisite frescoes. Thirty-four windows illuminate the library even on dull and rainy days.</p>
                                        <p>The library holds between 160,000 and 170,000 priceless texts and manuscripts, including Bibles, liturgical texts, theological works, and medical texts. Many of the texts were brought by monks from Ireland and are in Irish. The library also holds the earliest known architectural plan of the cathedral, which is on parchment paper.</p>
                                        <p>The library holds between 160,000 and 170,000 priceless texts and manuscripts, including Bibles, liturgical texts, theological works, and medical texts. Many of the texts were brought by monks from Ireland and are in Irish. The library also holds the earliest known architectural plan of the cathedral, which is on parchment paper.</p>
                                        <p>
                                            This picturesque journey of just over 2 hours weaves through rolling moors and lake vistas before arriving in St. Gallen’s UNESCO World Heritage-listed Abbey District.You can also combine a visit to St Gallen with other amazing <a href="/blog/10-things-to-do-in-lucerne-switzerland" class="lnks" target="_blank">things to do in Lucerne</a> .
                                        </p>
                                    </li>

                                    <li data-index="9">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Basel Kunstmuseum</h2>
                                        <p>The Basel Kunstmuseum, spread over three buildings, is the world’s oldest museum owned by a municipality and open to the public. It features an impressive and diverse collection of over 300,000 pieces of art spanning eight centuries, from the Middle Ages to the present.</p>
                                        <p>
                                            Its main collection, the Amerbach Cabinet, is a collection of precious works from the 15th and 16th centuries, acquired by the city in 1661 and made accessible to the public.The Hauptbau building showcases works from the 17th to 19th centuries, as well as collections of medieval and Renaissance art.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>A third building, the Gegenwart, was opened in 1980 and is dedicated to contemporary art.</p>
                                        <p>Basel is also home to many other unique museums, such as the Tinguely Museum and the Paper Museum, which are free with the Swiss Travel Pass.</p>
                                    </li>

                                    <li data-index="10">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Scenic Boat Rides on Lake Geneva</h2>
                                        <p>At the southwestern tip of Switzerland lies Lake Geneva (Lac Léman), one of Central Europe’s largest and most picturesque inland lakes, which shares its shores with both Switzerland and France.</p>
                                        <p>Cruising the lake is a delight: CGN (Compagnie Générale de Navigation sur le lac Léman) operates scheduled public boat services that are included with the Swiss Travel Pass (except for special event cruises). The boats dock at gorgeous lakeside towns like Montreux, Lausanne, and Vevey, where one can get off, explore the city, and then continue on the next ship onward.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Popular routes or stops: </h3>
                                        <br />
                                        <br />

                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Montreux to Château Chillon</h3>
                                        <p>Whether sailing from Montreux or another lakeside town, a stop at Château de Chillon is undoubtedly one of the highlights, drawing travelers from all over the globe to explore its rich and layered history.</p>
                                        <p>This island castle has stood still through the centuries, serving as a prison, fortress, residence, and an inspiration for poets such as Lord Byron.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Geneva to Lausanne</h3>
                                        <p>This stretch takes you past some of the region’s most iconic landmarks — from the Jet d’Eau, Geneva’s dramatic fountain that shoots water 140 metres skyward, to the sweeping terraces of the Lavaux vineyard-terraces — a UNESCO World Heritage site of steep, sun-drenched slopes rising above Lake Geneva.</p>
                                        <p>Make the most of the day by combining a lake cruise with some other shore activities at various places along the way. Hop off at Vevey and visit <a href="/mountain-excursion/37-chaplin-world" class="lnks" target="_blank">Chaplin's World</a>, an innovative museum dedicated to Charlie Chaplin, or hop off at the stop for the Chillon Castle, or discover the city of Geneva and its chocolates on a <a href="/attractions/chocolate-tour-of-geneva/?id=act_c13233ea-dd47-4864-af1c-0f1b1326e221" class="lnks" target="_blank">Chocolate tour of Geneva</a>.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-bookCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-left">
                                                <img src="/images/Mountains/chaplin-world-medium1.webp" alt="">
                                            </div>
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-right">
                                                <p class="bookButton">Chaplin's World</p>
                                                <a href="/en-in/mountain-excursion/37-chaplin-world" class="bordered-btn gray" target="_blank">Book Now</a>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </li>

                                    <li data-index="11">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Lugano’s Art and Culture Museums</h2>
                                        <p>There’s something magical about Lugano. Tucked between lake and mountain, its beauty feels like a painted work of art. Whether you’re a seasoned art lover or someone who stops to appreciate a sculpture in a town square, garden, or park, Lugano offers artistic surprises at every turn.</p>
                                        <p>Lugano's art and culture museums are a testament to its rich artistic heritage. At the centre of its art scene is the MASI - Museo d’Arte della Svizzera Italiana, which offers a mix of contemporary art spanning the 19th and 20th centuries, with an emphasis on Swiss-Italian artists.</p>
                                        <p>It spans two spaces: The LAC (Lugano Arte e Cultura), a cultural centre devoted to the visual and performing arts and music, and the Palazzo Reali, which focuses on local Ticino art history, with an emphasis on older art, mainly from the 15th to the early 20th century.</p>
                                        <p>The cultural centre MUSEC (Museo delle Culture) is located on Lugano's lakeside in the historic Villa Malpensata. The centre hosts exhibitions and events dedicated to contemporary art, photography, ethnic, and Oriental arts.</p>
                                        <p>Combine an artistic day of art in Lugano with some fun family time at the <a href="/mountain-excursion/14-swiss-miniatur" class="lnks" target="_blank">Swiss Miniatur</a> (Switzerland’s largest open-air miniature museum) at Melide, just a short train or boat ride away from Lugano.</p>

                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/Family-enjoying-at-swiss-miniatur.webp" alt="A family enjoying at the Swiss Miniatur, one of the hidden gems with Swiss Travel Pass" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>

                                        <p>These are just a few of the great places that you can visit for free or at discounted rates with the Swiss Travel Pass. The pass does so much more than just take you from place to place; it is the key to unlocking treasures at every corner.</p>
                                        <p>With it, you can take spontaneous boat trips, visit quirky and lesser-known museums, and see exhibitions at cultural centres. Add to this the free transport on all public buses, boats, trains, and trams, not forgetting that kids under 16 travel free!</p>
                                        <p>All that's left to do is pack your curiosity, trust the magic of the Swiss Travel Pass, and start looking for the hidden gems on your Swiss pleasure hunt.</p>
                                    </li>

                                </ul>


                            </div>

                                    <li class="in-view">
                                        <p>The word Switzerland evokes so many things to mind…smooth as silk chocolate, melt-in-your-mouth cheese, and towering Alpine scenes that are the very soul of this amazing little country. Chocolates and cheese are joys that one can easily find, but the mountains can be somewhat of a daunting puzzle.</p>
                                        <p>Which ones to visit? Are they worth the price? Are they all the same? Where can we find the best deals and discounts? Let's strip away the mystery surrounding these snowcapped giants so that you can make an informed decision on the best peaks and discounts available in Switzerland's mountains.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/Couple-enjoying-a-hot-bath.webp" alt="Couple enjoying a hot bath looking at the Mountains of Switzerland" />

It offers unlimited travel on all public transport modes for the chosen number of days, access to over 500 museums, and incredible discounts on mountain excursions. The cherry on the cake: your kids under 16 travel free, not just on trains, but also on mountain excursions!</p>

                                    <li data-index="1">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Jungfraujoch - Top of Europe</h2>
                                        <p>Jungfrau, one of the most popular mountain excursions in Switzerland, offers breathtaking views of the Aletsch Glacier—the longest glacier in the Swiss Alps —inspiring awe and wonder.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Getting there:</h3>
                                        <p>There are two ways to get to <a href="/en-in/mountain-excursion/1-jungfraujoch-top-of-europe" class="lnks" target="_blank">Jungfraujoch in Europe</a></p>
                                        <p><b>Option 1:</b> Take the train from Interlaken Ost (East) station, with changes at Lauterbrunnen and Grindelwald. The time taken on this route is 2 hours.</p>
                                        <p><b>Option 2:</b> Take the train from Interlaken Ost to Grindelwald, then use the cable car to reach the Eigergletscher station. Finally, take another train to the highest railway station in Europe. The total travel time on this route is 1.15 hours.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">At the peak</h3>
                                        <p>Visit the Sphinx Terrace at 3571 metres for the best views of the surrounding Alps</p>
                                        <p>Walk through the Alpine Sensation - a 250-metre-long tunnel showcasing the history of the Jungfrau railways.</p>
                                        <p>Tread carefully inside the Ice Palace, a frosty tunnel with sub-zero temperatures and fantastic ice sculptures of creatures that seem literally ‘frozen’ in time.</p>
                                        <p>Try your hand at snow tubing, ziplining, and snowboarding at the Snow Fun Park. Keep in mind, this is a summer park and typically open from May through October.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/Snowy-peak-at-Jungfraujoch.webp" alt="Snowy peak of Jungfraujoch - Experiencing the Mountains of Switzerland should be on your bucket list" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Discount with the Swiss Travel Pass</h3>
                                        <p>A full fare adult ticket costs SFr 224. However, with the <a href="/swiss-travel-pass" class="lnks" target="_blank">Swiss Travel Pass</a>, you can get the same at a discounted rate of SFr 149.</p>

                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="2">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Mount Titlis</h2>
                                        <p>Nestled in the village of Engelberg, not too far from Lucerne, is the beautiful <a href="/en-in/mountain-excursion/5-mount-titlis" class="lnks" target="_blank">Mount Titlis</a>. Standing at 3020 metres, Mount Titlis offers not just gorgeous views but also great fun activities and the super-popular Titlis Rotair —the world’s first rotating cable car.</p>

                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Getting there:</h3>
                                        <p>Engelberg is a 45-minute train ride from Lucerne. From here, a short walk or public bus ride gets you to the Titlis Valley station, from where you hop on to two cable cars (including the Titlis Rotair - the world's first revolving cable car) to the peak.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">At the peak</h3>
                                        <p>After the exhilarating ride in the Titlis Rotair, head for the Titlis Cliff Walk, Europe’s highest suspension bridge at 3041 metres. Brave the 100 metre walk and enjoy views from 500 metres above the ground.</p>
                                        <p>For great views, head to the viewing platform before walking into the Glacier Cave, a 150-metre-long tunnel carved 10 metres below the glacier and adorned with surreal ice sculptures. </p>
                                        <p>Ride the Ice Flyer Chairlift across the glacier with gorgeous views over deep crevasses. The chairlift takes you to Glacier Park in the summer (mid-May through August) and the ski slopes in winter.</p>
                                        <p>For the adventurous, the SnowXpark at Trubsee (a midway station before the Rotair) offers activities such as ziplining, moonbiking, and sledging.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-bookCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-left">
                                                <img src="/images/Mountains/Swiss-Transport-Museum-medium3.webp" alt="" />
                                            </div>
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-right">
                                                <p class="bookButton">Swiss Transport Museum</p>
                                                <a href="/en-in/mountain-excursion/35-swiss-transport-museum" class="bordered-btn gray" target="_blank">Book Now</a>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>A day to Mt Titlis can also be combined with other great attractions in Lucerne, like the <a href="/en-in/mountain-excursion/34-saphir-panoramic-yacht-cruise" class="lnks" target="_blank">Saphir Panorama Yacht Cruise</a> on Lake Lucerne or the <a href="/en-in/mountain-excursion/35-swiss-transport-museum" class="lnks" target="_blank">Swiss Museum of Transport</a>, the most visited museum in Switzerland.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/Peaks-of-Mount-Titlis-Switzerland-most-accessible-alpine.webp" alt="Picturesque View of Mount Titlis, among the mountains of Switzerland; it is considered one of the most accessible Alpine peaks." />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Discount with the Swiss Travel Pass</h3>
                                        <p>A full-fare adult ticket to Mt. Titlis costs SFr 114 (including an ice flyer chairlift ride). However, if you hold a Swiss Travel Pass, you can get the same at a discounted rate of SFr 63.</p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="3">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Matterhorn Glacier Paradise</h2>
                                        <p>Towering above the mountain village of Zermatt is the mighty Matterhorn, the most photographed mountain in the world! The <a href="/en-in/mountain-excursion/7-matterhorn-glacier-paradise" class="lnks" target="_blank">Matterhorn Glacier Paradise</a>  (also known as the Kleine Matterhorn) is one of the best places to get perfect pictures of the unique triangular massif of the Matterhorn.</p>
                                        <p>Ride up in a series of gondolas to Europe’s highest cable car station at 3883 metres for glorious views and an amazing Alpine experience.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Getting there:</h3>
                                        <p>Walk around 20 minutes or take a bus (number 571/2) from Zermatt station to the Matterhorn Express valley station. From here, you reach the peak via a series of 3 cable cars with changes at the midway stations Furi and Trockner Steg.</p>
                                        <p>If you are arriving in Zermatt from St Moritz or Chur, you can take a ride on the <a href="/mountain-excursion/43-glacier-express" class="lnks" target="_blank">Glacier Express </a>, the world’s slowest express train, and globally, one of the most sought-after panoramic train journeys.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">At the peak</h3>
                                        <p>First things first —head to the viewing platform for a 360-degree panoramic view that stretches as far as Italy and France.</p>
                                        <p>Walk through the Glacier Palace located 15 metres under the glacier. Enjoy significant lighting effects, a slide-through ice tunnel, and fantastic ice sculptures.</p>
                                        <p>Step into Europe’s highest cinema and watch some interesting films on the fascinating Alpine world around Zermatt. Ski on the Theodul glacier, the only area where skiing is possible in the summer.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/Matterhorn-Glacier-Gondola-Ride.webp" alt="Matterhorn Glacier, one of the most beautiful mountains of Switzerland, acts as a backdrop for a Gondola." />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>

                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Discount with the Swiss Travel Pass</h3>
                                        <p>A full-fare adult ticket costs SFr 95. However, if you hold a Swiss Travel Pass, you can get the same at a discounted rate of SFr 48.</p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="4">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Grindelwald First - Top of Adventure</h2>
                                        <p>Nothing like a mountain full of fun, and that's just what the First is. Offering fantastic views, a lake, a picnic area, and a range of super activities, this is the perfect mountain for family adventure. The short cableway up and numerous fun ways to descend make the First experience truly unique.</p>
                                        <p>If you want to add even more adventure, visit the <a href="/attractions/glacier-canyon-grindelwald/?id=act_d2f762b7-6606-458b-811c-6a9611d9b21b" class="lnks" target="_blank">Grindelwald Glacier Canyon</a>  and enjoy a unique sensory walk through its exposed rock galleries and tunnels.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-bookCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-left">
                                                <img src="https://d3rr2gvhjw0wwy.cloudfront.net/uploads/activity_headers/325590/2000x2000-0-70-1565b4f2c65244a4bf32c03f5ee69c8f.jpg" alt="Grindelwald Glacier Canyon" />
                                            </div>
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-right">
                                                <p class="bookButton">Grindelwald Glacier Canyon</p>
                                                <a href="/attractions/glacier-canyon-grindelwald/?id=act_d2f762b7-6606-458b-811c-6a9611d9b21b" class="bordered-btn gray" target="_blank">Book Now</a>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Getting there:</h3>
                                        <p>The <a href="/en-in/mountain-excursion/9-grindelwald-first" class="lnks" target="_blank">Grindelwald First </a>(Firstbahn) station is just a short walk away from Grindelwald railway station. From here, a ride on the cable car via the midway stations Bort and Schrekfeld takes you to the First.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-bookCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-left">
                                                <img src="/images/Mountains/Grindelwald-First-medium1.webp" alt="Grindelwald First" />
                                            </div>
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-right">
                                                <p class="bookButton">Grindelwald First</p>
                                                <a href="/en-in/mountain-excursion/9-grindelwald-first" class="bordered-btn gray" target="_blank">Book Now</a>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">At the peak</h3>
                                        <p>Walk along the winding Cliff Walk by Tissot for glorious views from 2168 metres.</p>
                                        <p>Go on a short hike to the picnic spot at Lake Bachalpsee, where you can even swim in the summer months.</p>
                                        <p>For your descent, choose one or all of the activities (select all, you will not regret it). Fly down an 800-metre cable in an individual seat on the First Flyer, then get horizontally strapped to a massive eagle and fly face down on the First Glider. Following this, ride a mountain cart down a 3-km route, then hop on a trotti bike for the final leg of the descent.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/Sunset-at-Grindelwald-First.webp" alt="One of the most beautiful sunsets at one of the most beautiful mountains of Switzerland, at Grindelwald First." />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Discount with the Swiss Travel Pass</h3>
                                        <p>
                                            You can either purchase a cable car ticket alone or a ticket that includes one or more activities. Let us presume that you will want to do at least one activity, so let's go with that -
                                                A full-fare adult ticket with one activity costs SFr 82. However, if you hold a <a href="/swiss-travel-pass" class="lnks" target="_blank">Swiss Travel Pass </a>, you can get the same at a discounted rate of SFr 54.
                                        </p>
                                        <p>
                                            <b>Note:</b> It is wise to pre-purchase a ticket that includes the number of activities you want to do.
                                                The mountain cart and trottibike operate in the summer only (typically May through the end of October).
                                        </p>
                                        <p>Keep in mind that all of these activities have age/weight/height restrictions as well.</p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="5">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Gornergrat</h2>
                                        <p>Conveniently starting from the heart of Zermatt, the journey via Switzerland’s first fully electric and Europe’s highest open-air railway gets you to the Gornergrat. After travelling over bridges, through tunnels, and past forests, you'll be rewarded with the most glorious views at the peak. Other than the Matterhorn (which, some say, is best viewed from here), the view of twenty-nine 4000-metre peaks, including Mont Blanc in France, is just stunning.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Getting there:</h3>
                                        <p>Just across the road from Zermatt central station is the Zermatt GGB station, from where you board the train for a roughly 40-minute ride to the peak at 3100 metres.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">At the peak</h3>
                                        <p>Take a short hike down to the Riffelsee to view the reflection of the Matterhorn in the lake and click some memorable photographs. Wander through the Alpine garden with over 500 native species of plants.</p>
                                        <p>Go for a nature-spotting walk to find native alpine creatures like the elusive marmots and black nosed sheep.</p>
                                        <p>Visit the ZOOOM the Matterhorn experience for an interactive experience. See the Matterhorn up close with the Periscope feature, enjoy a 3D cinematic experience of the Matterhorn across various seasons, and virtually paraglide over Alpine panoramas in 3D glasses.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/Beautiful-landscape-at-Gornergrat.webp" alt="Two trains in a beautiful landscape of Gornergrat." />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Discount with the Swiss Travel Pass</h3>
                                        <p>A full-fare adult ticket costs SFr 132. However, if you hold a Swiss Travel Pass, you can get the same at a discounted rate of SFr 66.</p>

                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="6">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Harder Kulm</h2>
                                        <p>Interlaken’s home mountain, <a href="/en-in/mountain-excursion/2-harder-kulm" class="lnks" target="_blank">Harder Kulm </a>, is a small mountain that is big on views. Just a few minutes away from Interlaken Ost station, the journey via the historic funicular (operating since 1908) offers views over Lakes Thun and Brienz, and the surrounding Bernese Oberland region. </p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Getting there:</h3>
                                        <p>The Harder Kulm is accessed via a 10-minute funicular ride from the Harderbahn station, just a short walk away from Interlaken Ost station. </p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">At the peak</h3>
                                        <p>Walk to the Two-Lakes lookout point for the most breathtaking view of Lake Brienz to the left and Lake Thun to the right. Nestled between these two is the picturesque town of Interlaken (Interlaken literally means ‘between 2 lakes’).</p>
                                        <p>Have a meal with a view of the very popular castle-like Panorama restaurant (reservation recommended). It's a perfect place to unwind at sunset after a day of sightseeing, when the region is bathed in twilight's glow.</p>
                                        <p>Walk along the circular Harder Kulm route through the shady mountain forest for a different view over the surrounding region and lakes.</p>
                                        <p>Since the trip to Harder Kulm is a half-day activity, you can combine it with other activities in <a href="/blog/things-to-do-in-interlaken" class="lnks" target="_blank">Interlaken</a> . Interlaken is the home of Swiss adventure activities and other fun experiences like the truly Swiss <a href="/attractions/raclette-rafting-interlaken/?id=act_17e96a97-9ef5-43f6-8473-cd75d58c531f" class="lnks" target="_blank">Raclette Rafting </a>or the adrenaline-pumping <a href="/adventure-tours/scenic-jetboat-ride/?id=act_2ba016e1-514e-422c-b4f9-07884e6b6aa8" class="lnks" target="_blank">scenic jetboat ride</a>  on Lake Brienz.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/Harder-Kulm-viewed-from-a-viewing-platform.webp" alt="Two kids and a cow at the Viewing Platform of Harder Kulm." />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>

                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Discount with the Swiss Travel Pass</h3>
                                        <p>A full-fare adult ticket costs SFr 44. However, if you hold a Swiss Travel Pass, you can get the same at a discounted rate of SFr 22.</p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="7">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Mount Pilatus</h2>
                                        <p>Known for its Golden Round Trip, Pilatus, also referred to as the Dragon Mountain, is replete with legends. Not too far from Lucerne, it is a convenient day trip and a family-friendly mountain offering activities for all ages. </p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Getting there:</h3>
                                        <p>Take a bus ride from Lucerne to Kriens, followed by a short walk to the <a href="/en-in/mountain-excursion/6-mount-pilatus" class="lnks" target="_blank">Mt. Pilatus </a>cablecar station. From here, hop on to the Panorama gondolas to the midway point of Frakmunteg, followed by the Dragon Ride aerial cableway to the peak. </p>
                                        <p>For the descent, take the world’s steepest cogwheel railway (gradient of 48 degrees) to Alpnachstad and then sail back to Lucerne by boat. This complete journey is possible in the summer months (typically mid-May through mid-October)</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">At the peak</h3>
                                        <p>Take in the unparalleled views of over 70 peaks and serene lakes around Lucerne and the surrounding region. Take an adventurous walk along the Drachenweg (dragon trail), a path carved into the mountainside offering stunning views over Lake Lucerne.</p>
                                        <p>
                                            Make a halt at the midway point of Frakmuntegg to enjoy the activities on offer. 
                                            Take an exhilarating ride on the longest summer toboggan run stretching 1350 metres. 
                                            Enjoy the rope park, which offers 10 courses and exciting ziplines. Kids aged 4 to 8 have a dedicated rope park tailored to their skill levels.
                                        </p>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/Panoramic-view-of-Mount-Pilatus.webp" alt="A panoramic view of Mount Pilatus, one of the most beautiful mountains of Switzerland" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Discount with the Swiss Travel Pass</h3>
                                        <p>A full-fare adult ticket costs SFr 80. However, if you hold a Swiss Travel Pass, you can get the same at a discounted rate of SFr 40.</p>

                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="8">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Mount Rigi</h2>
                                        <p>Lovingly called the Queen of the Mountains, Mt. Rigi is one of the lower peaks just east of Lucerne and a perfect place for a picturesque day trip. This mountain, just under 1800 metres, has nine trains and cable cars that take you to it through stunning views of lakes and green, wildflower-covered pastures. The Vitznau-Rigi railway was Europe’s first mountain railway, opening in 1871.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Getting there:</h3>
                                        <p>With multiple trains and cableways, there are various travel options. Let's have a look at the three main ways to get to Mt Rigi from Lucerne. </p>
                                        <p><b>Option 1: </b>By train to Arth Goldau, followed by the cogwheel to Rigi.</p>
                                        <p><b>Option 2: </b>By train to Vitznau, followed by the cogwheel to Rigi (one can also take a train/bus combination to Vitznau).</p>
                                        <p><b>Option 3: </b>By boat to Weggis and then the cable car to Rigi. However, this requires an uphill climb to the cable car station.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">At the peak</h3>
                                        <p>Walk along the paved path to the mountain's highest point for great views. The fenced-in viewing areas also make it safe for kids. You can also climb the weather tower for a higher vantage point (though not much higher).</p>
                                        <p>Peek into the lovely stone chapel, aptly named Regina Montium (Queen of the Mountains).</p>
                                        <p>Rigi offers over 100 km of well-paved hiking trails of varying difficulty levels to suit all types of travelers. These trails are the perfect way to take in views of the shimmering lakes, the surrounding region, and the peaks.</p>
                                        <p>Have a snack or meal at one of the restaurants, either at the peak or at  Rigi Kaltbad, one of the lower stations.</p>
                                        <p>Visit the spa at Rigi Kaltbad (literally meaning 'cold bath') and pamper yourself with a dip in one of the indoor or outdoor pools while gazing at the fantastic scenery. You can have a snack or a meal at one of the restaurants. If you're traveling with kids, consider visiting the mini golf course and playground at Kaltbad. </p>
                                        <p>Visit the Chaserenholz cheese dairy and take a tour. The dairy is accessed via a 20-minute downhill walk from the peak. They even offer popular local cheese dishes, such as raclette and fondue.</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/Two-hikers-at-Mount Rigi.webp" alt="Two hikers going through the hiking route of Mount Rigi." />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Discount with the Swiss Travel Pass</h3>
                                        <p>A full-fare adult ticket costs SFr 78. However, if you hold a Swiss Travel Pass, you can travel absolutely Free.</p>

                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="9">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Using the Swiss Travel Pass for mountain excursions:</h2>
                                        <p>As you can see from the list above of the most popular mountains, the discounts offered with the Swiss Travel Pass range from 25% to 100%. Using the Swiss Travel Pass on trains and other modes of transport is super easy. </p>

                                        <p>Just keep either a paper or a downloaded pass on your smartphone, and present it to the bus or train ticket checker. For the mountains, simply show your pass at the ticket counter of the mountain railways or cable cars to receive the relevant discount. You can also view detailed rate cards and pre-purchase your tickets <a href="/mountain-excursion" class="lnks" target="_blank">here </a>. </p>

                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="10">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Making the most of Switzerland’s mountain excursions:</h2>
                                        <p>It is almost certain that you will want to visit at least a couple of mountains on even the shortest trip to Switzerland. Based on your preferences, the region you'll be staying in, and your budget, it's advisable to make an informed choice. Try to get diverse experiences at each one.</p>
                                        <p><u>Snow:</u> Try to visit at least one mountain that guarantees snow year-round. Jungfrau, Titlis, and Matterhorn guarantee snow 365 days a year.</p>
                                        <p><u>Adventure:</u> Choose a mountain with toboggan runs, ziplines, trotti bikes, and kid-friendly activities, and more. Grindelwald First or Mt Pilatus would be a good choice for this.</p>
                                        <p><u>Photography: </u>Switzerland offers great photo ops at every turn, but nothing compares to the iconic shot of the Matterhorn. Head for the Matterhorn Glacier Paradise or the Gornergrat. Try the 5-Lakes walk at Gornergrat to capture the reflection of the Matterhorn in the lakes. </p>
                                        <p><u>Promotions:</u> Look out for the best deals on the Swiss Travel Pass and mountains. There are often ‘extra-day’ or ‘class-upgrade’ promotions on the Swiss Travel Pass during the off-season. </p>
                                        <p><u>Do your homework:</u> Make sure to check if the intended mountains are fully or partially included in the Swiss Travel Pass, the weather on each around the time of travel, the best time of day to beat the crowds, the best time for photography, etc.</p>
                                        <p>Get the most out of your Switzerland holiday with the Swiss Travel Pass- it is your ticket to comfort, convenience, flexibility, and savings. Make sure you take advantage of discounts on mountains, museums, and other attractions. Wait no further, lace up your hiking boots, pack the woolies, grab the camera, and set off for the Alps!</p>
                                    </li>
                                </ul>

                                        <%-- <h2 class="bdm-title">Swiss Travel Pass vs Half Fare Card – Which One Truly Saves You More? </h2> --%>
                                        <p>If you’ve started planning your Switzerland trip, you have probably run into the tough decision: which travel pass is right for you? With so many options out there, it almost feels like someone designed them to confuse you and make you spend more, not less.</p>
                                        <p>For a regular tourist who wants to crisscross the country in a limited amount of time, the two main passes that come to mind are the Swiss Travel Pass and the Half Fare Card. So which one is right for you?</p>
                                        <p>Let's try to break this down with the following points, even though the annoying answer at the end will be ‘it depends on your personal budget and itinerary’</p>
                                        <p>●	What Is the Swiss Travel Pass? </p>
                                        <p>●	What Is the Swiss Half Fare Card? </p>
                                        <p>●	When does the Swiss Travel Pass shine for you? </p>
                                        <p>●	When is the Half Fare Card the better choice?</p>
                                        <p>●	Families and groups, solo travellers and couples. Which one? </p>
                                        <p>●	Swiss Travel Pass and Half Fare Card Prices by Duration </p>
                                        <p>●	Swiss Travel Pass versus Half Fare Card: Sample itineraries and costs</p>
                                        <p>●	Can we combine the Swiss Travel Pass and the Half Fare Card?</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/a-family-enjoying-holiday-in-switzerland.webp" alt="Swiss Travel Pass vs Half Fare Card - A family enjoying their holiday in Switzerland" />

                                    <li data-index="1">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">What is the Swiss Travel Pass?</h2>
                                        <p>The most popular pass for travellers planning to spend one to two weeks in Switzerland is the <a target="_blank" href="/swiss-travel-pass" class='lnks'>Swiss Travel Pass</a> . It allows you to travel without the hassle of having to purchase tickets per segment on the go and without the fear of being penalised for hopping onto the wrong train (which may not be unlikely)</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Benefits of the Swiss Travel Pass: </h3>
                                        <p>●	Unlimited travel on all modes of public transport</p>
                                        <p>●	Free rides on panoramic trains like Glacier Express, Bernina Express, etc (seat reservations need to be paid for, however)</p>
                                        <p>●	Free entrance to over 500 museums</p>
                                        <p>●	Substantial discounts on most mountain railways </p>
                                        <p>●	Great family benefits with kids under 16 travel free</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Classes</h3>
                                        <p>1st and 2nd class</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Duration</h3>
                                        <p>3,4,6,8, and 15 days that are used either consecutively or non-consecutively (Flexi pass) within a period of 1 month.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">How to use the Swiss Travel Pass</h3>
                                        <p>Once you have purchased the pass, simply hop on the trains or buses and flash the card when asked by the ticket checker.</p>

                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/family-of-four-enjoying-holidays-on the snowy-mountains.webp" alt="Family of four enjoying holidays in the snowy mountains, Excursions getting reasonable discounts through the Swiss Travel Pass" />
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>For mountain excursions, present your pass at the ticket counter to receive the applicable discount, or show your pass along with your pre-purchased <a href="/mountain-excursion" class="lnks" target="_blank">mountain excursion</a> ticket/voucher.</p>

                                    <li data-index="2">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title" style="line-height: 1">What is the Half Fare Card?</h2>
                                        <p>The Half Fare Card is a good option for those who want to stay in the country for a little longer (over two weeks) and enjoy more flexibility with their time.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Benefits of the Half-Fare Card</h3>
                                        <p>50% discount on all public transport </p>
                                        <p>50% discount on mountain excursions, including Jungfraujoch</p>
                                        <p>Great family benefits with kids under 16 travel free</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Classes</h3>
                                        <p>1st and 2nd class</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">Duration</h3>
                                        <p>One month</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt">How to use the Swiss Half Fare Card</h3>
                                        <p>Once you have purchased the <a href="/swiss-travel-pass" class="lnks" target="_blank">Swiss Half Fare Card</a>, you must purchase individual tickets for each journey. Keep in mind that the earlier you buy them, the better your chances of getting lower fares.</p>
                                    </li>
                                    <li data-index="3">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">So…which pass should you choose?</h2>

                                        <p>Now that we have the basics, how do we choose our pass? Who should choose the Swiss Travel Pass, and who should choose the Half Fare Card?</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt" style="line-height: 1">When does the Swiss Travel Pass shine for you?</h3>
                                        <p>If you are traveling intensively for a short duration and, like any tourist (including myself), want to cram in as much as you can. </p>
                                        <p>
                                            When you want total flexibility and the convenience of not having to purchase tickets on the go.If you want to ride the scenic trains, such as the <a href="/mountain-excursion/42-bernina-express" class="lnks" target="_blank">Bernina Express</a> or the <a href="/mountain-excursion/43-glacier-express" class="lnks" target="_blank">Glacier Express</a>.
                                        </p>
                                        <div class="bdm-placeCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-placeCard-image">

                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>If you are a fan of museums (and Switzerland has many great ones to explore).</p>
                                        <p>If you don’t want the hassle of planning a specific train for each journey, and prefer to play it by ear. When you don't want to worry about hopping onto the wrong train and having to repurchase a ticket for the correct one.</p>
                                        <p>When you are the spontaneous type and will make a quick decision to visit, say, the <a href="/en-in/mountain-excursion/7-matterhorn-glacier-paradise" class="lnks" target="_blank">Matterhorn Glacier Paradise</a> Paradise or take a ride on the <a href="/mountain-excursion/56-luzern-interlaken-express" class="lnks" target="_blank">Lucerne-Interlaken Express</a> on a day that you have kept free to relax.</p>
                                        <h3 class="inlinetxt" style="line-height: 1">When is the Half Fare Card the better choice?</h3>
                                        <p>When you are willing to do a bit of math, plan well in advance, and pre-purchase tickets for every journey. When you have a stay that exceeds 15 days, which is the maximum duration of the Swiss Travel Pass.</p>
                                        <p>When your plans are fluid. If you haven't made a detailed plan and are unsure if the Swiss Travel Pass is worth the investment.</p>
                                        <p>When <a href="/en-in/mountain-excursion/1-jungfraujoch-top-of-europe" class="lnks" target="_blank">Jungfraujoch</a> is a definite inclusion, the Half Fare Card gives a 50% discount on the Jungfraujoch (versus the Swiss Travel Pass, which offers a 25% discount).</p>

                                        <p>Well, this is an entirely personal choice.</p>
                                        <p>For families, although both the Swiss Travel Pass and the Half Fare Card offer the same family benefits, the Swiss Travel Pass is the better choice for large families or groups.</p>
                                        <p>This is simply because of the convenience and the zero risk if you miss or skip a train due to crowds.</p>
                                        <p>Yes, it may be a tad more expensive, especially if you don't need to travel daily. Still, it makes up for this in convenience, flexibility, and value-added features, such as complimentary museum entrances.</p>
                                        <p>For solo travellers and couples, if the daily program is well-planned in advance and you are willing to spend time searching for good deals and booking specific trains, the Swiss Half Fare Card will likely be a slightly cheaper option.</p>

                                    <li class="in-view">
                                        <p>If you are planning a trip to Switzerland, one of the most important decisions that you will make is choosing the correct travel Pass. As a country, Switzerland is made to be explored. Other than the massive Alpine peaks and pristine lakes, there are hidden treasures in every corner that a correct travel pass will help you to reach.</p>
                                        <p>Enter the Swiss Travel Pass, the all-in-one golden ticket that is the perfect travel companion for a short holiday. Let's have a look at everything you need to know about this pass and how it works.</p>
                                        <p>●	What Is the Swiss Travel Pass</p>
                                        <p>●	Types of Swiss Travel Passes</p>

                                    <li data-index="1">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">What is the Swiss Travel Pass?</h2>
                                        <p>The <a target="_blank" href="/swiss-travel-pass" class='lnks'>Swiss Travel Pass</a> is a must-have document for every traveler. It may sound like a travel document, but it is a golden ticket to Switzerland’s transport, attractions, and more. With it, you can move seamlessly from big, buzzing cities to tiny, quaint villages, snowy Alpine peaks, and across emerald lakes.</p>
                                        <p>●	<b><u>Transport</u></b>: The pass gives you unlimited travel on all public transport modes in the country. You can travel on trains, buses, trams, boats, and cableways for the number of days chosen. </p>
                                        <p>●	<b><u>Mountain Excursions</u></b>: The pass offers you free access to a couple of mountain excursions and substantial discounts on most other mountain railways and cableway</p>
                                        <p>●	<b><u>Museums</u></b>: The Swiss Travel Pass doubles as a museum pass, granting free access to over 500 museums in Switzerland.</p>
                                        <p>●	<b><u>Family benefits</u></b>: Last, but definitely not least, your children under 16 years travel totally free on the transport network and on mountain excursions!</p>
                                        <div class="bdm-bookCard">
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-left">
                                                <img src="/images/Blog/swiss-travel-pass.jpg" alt="Swiss Travel Pass" />
                                            </div>
                                            <div class="bdm-bookCard-right">
                                                <p class="bookButton">Swiss Travel Pass</p>
                                                <a href="/swiss-travel-pass" class="bordered-btn gray" target="_blank">Book Now</a>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>

                                    <li data-index="2">
                                        <h2 class="bdm-title">Types of Swiss Travel Passes</h2>

                                        <p>The Swiss Travel Pass comes in 2 versions - Consecutive and Flex.Both versions offer 1st- and 2nd-class travel and are available in durations of 3, 4, 6, 8, and 15 days.</p>

                                        <p>Both passes also offer a 30% discount to youth travellers aged 16-25. This youth discount, along with the Swiss Family Card, gives a significant price advantage to families.</p>

                                        <p><b><u>The Consecutive Day Pass</u></b> is validated for the chosen number of days from the first date of validity (usage) you enter whilst purchasing the pass.</p>

                                        <p>This pass is most beneficial when you are trying to cram in as much as possible within a short time frame. For example, if you have chosen a 4-day pass and want to travel to different towns almost each day, visit two mountain excursions and one or two museums.</p>

                                        <p><b><u>The Flex Pass</u></b> will also show the first date of validity you enter, but will allow you to use the chosen number of days non-consecutively within a one-month time frame.</p>

                                        <p>This version is more beneficial if you have a more extended stay and plan to hang out in your chosen towns for a few days rather than moving towns almost every day.</p>

                                        <p>You can request the <b><u>Swiss Family Card</u></b> when purchasing the Swiss Travel Pass. It is offered free of cost to children under 16 if the parents are Swiss Travel Pass holders. With this, the children can avail themselves of the same vast network of transportation, mountain railways, and museums, totally free.</p>

                                        <p>The <b><u>Swiss Travel Pass Youth</u></b> is offered to young travellers aged 16-25 and is an excellent way for them to explore the country at an affordable cost. The Youth Pass is available in both consecutive and flex versions.</p>
